author: Barry Berman

review: To start with, let me note that I am primarily a Netflix and iTunes user. I started out with a very nice Roku 2XS which worked just fine out of the box, detected and connected to my network, and functioned exactly as it was supposed to. Then... I realized my iTunes library was completely inaccessible and realized I'd made a mistake. So I ordered the Apple TV from Amazon. Here are my observations:1) The fit, finish and packaging for this most inexpensive of Apple's products is as good as anything else Apple makes. It does not appear like a stepchild in Apple's product line. It is an extremely tactile, compact, weighty little device with clean lines and is a perfect physical match for my new flat screen.2) The user interface is far and away superior to that for the Roku or any other similar device I've tried. Some thought has gone into their software for this device and it's the most usable in its class.3) The "channel" selection through AppleTV continues to grow, and so far as I can tell, this item offers more options that the Roku.4) The Airplay connectivity with my wireless PC works as expected. It's a very pleasant experience to find your complete iTunes media library accessible directly on your set without being forced to connect yet more cabling. I have a 2Wire router from AT&T; and the performance is easily good enough for high-def movies and TV shows. This is the main reason I went with this device. I am quite satisfied. I can now see new episodes of "Justified" and "Mad Men" when they come out on iTunes the day after the episodes air. You can't get everything in the most timely manner through iTunes (Game of Thrones? Hello? HBO?) but this is a large chunk of a good solution for people like me who refuse to subscribe to cable.I would eventually like to see Apple manufacture another version of this product with a 2-3 TB hard disk. I would absolutely consider buying such a device given that they can be trusted to put thought and design into the software to really make it work.
